meanings.def: the soft part in the mouth that moves around, used for tasting, swallowing, speaking, etc.
examples: He clicked his tongue to attract their attention.
She ran her tongue over her lips.
It's very rude to stick your tongue out at people.
The dog lay in a patch of shade with its tongue hanging out.
The snake's tongue flicked out of its mouth.

meanings.def: the tongue of some animals, cooked and eaten
examples: a slice of ox tongue

meanings.def: a language
examples: Even when we speak the same tongue we do not always understand one another.
I tried speaking to her in her native tongue.
The market place was full of people speaking many strange tongues.
She could hear men whispering in a foreign tongue.
She speaks English and Danish, though her native tongue is German.

meanings.def: a particular way of speaking
examples: He has a sharp tongue.
(formal) I'll thank you to keep a civil tongue in your head (= speak politely).

meanings.def: speaking in the way mentioned
examples: sharp-tongued

meanings.def: a long, narrow piece of leather under the laces on a shoe
something that is long and narrow and like a tongue in shape
examples: a tongue of flame

meanings.def: to stop yourself from saying something that might upset somebody or cause an argument, although you want to speak
examples: I didn't believe her explanation but I bit my tongue.

meanings.def: said to somebody, especially a child, who stays silent when expected to speak, for example after being asked a question
examples: What's the matter? Cat got your tongue?

meanings.def: to be able to speak or express your opinion
to pronounce a difficult word correctly
examples: He was having trouble getting his tongue around my name.

meanings.def: to talk too much, especially about things that are private
to say nothing although you would like to give your opinion
to make somebody talk more freely than usual
examples: A bottle of wine had loosened Harry's tongue.

meanings.def: if a word or name is on the tip of your tongue, you are sure that you know it but you cannot remember it
to be easy to say or pronounce
examples: It's not a name that exactly trips off the tongue, is it?

meanings.def: to cause people to start talking/people are talking about somebody’s private affairs
examples: His sudden resignation set tongues wagging.
This is a small island and tongues are beginning to wag.

meanings.def: a small mistake in something that you write or say
examples: Did I call you Richard? Sorry, Robert, just a slip of the tongue.
I didn't mean to say that—it was just a slip of the tongue.

meanings.def: to be careful what you say in order not to offend somebody or make them angry
if you say something with your tongue in your cheek, you are not being serious and mean it as a joke
